properties.media:imagetext:
COPY
WAR DEPARTIENT
HEADQUARTIRS NINIH CORPS AREA
OFFICE OF THE AIR OFFICER
Presidio of San Francisco, Calif.
October 6th, 1925.
Excerpt from 1st Lieut.
H. A. Moore's letter.
"In reply to your letter of September 15th to Golonel F. P. Lahn,
at present away from the City on a short leave of absence,
I am enclosing herewith
the sketch which you requested, together with some additional information on
landing field requirements and an estimate of
As the field stands to-day, the runvays - as I have placed them -
are
entirely too short to accommodate all
types of planes.
this matter in the right vay, the thing to do is to
If you want to go into
extend the runways on out
into the marshy ground - making them appriximately fifty yards wide and as
far
Northeast and Southeast as possible, bearing in mind the high power lines and
the fact that an obstacle at the edge of a field outs off seven feet of runway
for each obstacle of its own height. Perhaps three or four handred feet could
be added in this way.
According to the chart, the prevailing winds will permit
of landing into the Northwest and Southwest.
the field is too small for a
runay from Last to West, I have placed the hangars, shops, etcetera, along
the
West edge of the field next to the highway.
The entire portion of hard ground
must be dragged and smoothed before being used.
I would like to
suggest that if you care to laok into the future, when you
need a much larger airport, you might consider the proposition of having the
P. G. & E. power lines removed and filling in
the marshland to
the Bast, thereby
providing a field with a one-half mile runway last and West. In such event the
hangars
could be
located on the North and South side of the field.
You would
then have a sufficient area for every type of plane, together with a high
telephone, telegraph, or power line around a field is a
potential menaceto landing and taking off."
